content: Added "loop height write curve" to the stub generator.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Now we have an "etch a sketch", the old red drawing toy of my childhood. Yipee!

The solution is requiring several important principes of programming and of mathematics.
Congratulations for this good idea !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: La solution demandée met en œuvre plusieurs principes importants de la programmation et des mathématiques.
Bravo pour l'idée !
I think the puzzle is ready like this, as it is quite simple to learn, useful and very graphical. There aren't any other puzzles about Bézier curves currently, so this would be a nice addition.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It shows a nice and easy to learn interpolation scheme used commonly and is therefor a good learning opportunity. This is combined with simple loop and ASCII art programming, which makes it a good puzzle with a few different aspects.

I think in its current form the puzzle is already quite nice :) I am not quite sure why you want to have the points in the beginning of each line. Maybe consider working without the points completly, or fill the whole grid with points. Seems to me a bit more straightforward. I will approve it anyway, as I think its not a big deal.
For me, I would quit the clash immediatly : TLDR at its finest.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
I learned a lot from this problem

Hi alexcercos,

this looks like a nice exercise to play with ASCII art and printing of curves.

However I don't get exactly the point of the instructions: I guess you want the coder to construct the linear, than the quadratic and than the cubic curve. At least that is what I infer from the instructions. For me it was not quite clear what to do. "Interpolate" was not precise enough: How to interpolate? What do I need to do in order to follow the steps? With the help of wikipedia I inferred that I need to calculate the weights - here called "interpolation values" - from the number of steps and apply at every interpolation step.

Additionally one could just take the formula for the cubic curve and plug the numbers in using the weights as the curve parameters. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve#Cubic_B%C3%A9zier_curves

What was the original intention of the exercise? Do you want to let the coder carry out each interpolation step or are you fine with using the formula? The latter is not very much instructive concerning the Bézier curves but is instead more streamlined and focuses more on ASCII and printing.

Cheers

Hi thanks for your feedback, I noticed also that when searching for what an interpolation is on internet it doesn't give very clear results (and I should specify that those are "linear" interpolations). I updated the description and also added the formula. I also named the steps as weights in the description, that's a better way of naming it too (but I left them as "steps" where it should be clearer that it's something to be performed X times).

Even though the exercise would be intended to follow the instructions (and now I think it should be possible to get the result without doing any outside search), if anyone tried to use the formula directly he would get also the correct result but with more difficulty (it's shorter but more complex, basically all the interpolations collapsed) so I would be fine with that.

Hi thanks for your feedback and vote! The points at the beginning were needed because when using spaces they would be trimmed automatically (or the console ignore the empty lines, I don't fully remember but there were some issues when not having an initial character). Other option was to make a "frame" with other characters but there seem to be limitations on the amount of characters allowed as output (the high-resolution cases would need to be removed, I prefered to preserve them)

How can someone else other than the author change the title? Very unfortunate, can this still be fixed? The problem is indeed about cubic Bezier curves using the recursive definition via linear interpolation. Linear Bezier curves are just straight lines and definitely not what we have in the pictures!
